perturbation.changed_text:
8.2 Termination by Franchisor with Notice. Franchisor may terminate this Agreement upon ten (10) days written notice to Franchisee upon the occurrence of any of the following:

perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for termination due to non-payment to 10 days could be considered an unreasonably short timeframe, potentially violating good faith and fair dealing principles that are implied in contracts under New York law, which governs this agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under New York contract law.

perturbation.original_text: 10.2 Right to inspect and request information. During the Term, Franchisor shall have the right to conduct audits of Franchisee with respect to the Smaaash Centres, and inspect the Smaaash Centres, after providing a written notice of 5 (five) days. Franchisee shall be under an obligation to provide any information as may be requested by Franchisor with respect to the Smaaash Centres, including the books of accounts and other relevant documents or records maintained in relation to the Smaaash Centres.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.2 Right to inspect and request information. During the Term, Franchisor shall have the right to conduct audits of Franchisee with respect to the Smaaash Centres, and inspect the Smaaash Centres, after providing a verbal notice of 24 hours. Franchisee shall be under an obligation to provide any information as may be requested by Franchisor with respect to the Smaaash Centres, including the books of accounts and other relevant documents or records maintained in relation to the Smaaash Centres.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the notice period for audits to a verbal 24-hour notice is likely to be deemed unreasonable and may violate the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing, particularly considering the scope of information the Franchisee is obligated to provide. It also contradicts standard business practices requiring sufficient time to prepare for audits.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under New York contract law.

perturbation.original_text: 10.7 Force Majeure. The parties will not be liable to each other for any failure or delay in performance, other than failure to make timely payments due under this Agreement, if it is because of earthquake, flood, fire, acts of God, civil unrest, terrorism, acts of any governmental authority or any other reason beyond the reasonable control of either or both of the parties (“Force Majeure”). However, either party may terminate this Agreement by and upon notice to the other if the other is unable to perform any of its material obligations for a period of thirty (30) days by reason of a Force Majeure.
perturbation.changed_text: 10.7 Force Majeure. The parties will not be liable to each other for any failure or delay in performance, other than failure to make timely payments due under this Agreement, if it is because of earthquake, flood, fire, acts of God, civil unrest, terrorism, acts of any governmental authority or any other reason beyond the reasonable control of either or both of the parties (“Force Majeure”). However, either party may terminate this Agreement by and upon notice to the other if the other is unable to perform any of its material obligations for a period of five (5) days by reason of a Force Majeure.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the Force Majeure period for termination to five (5) days is extremely unreasonable. This is because a 5 day period is not considered enough time to get back on your feet. This goes against what Force Majeure is actually in place for.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York contract law and principles of Force Majeure
